recipe_title: How to Make the Best Pesto

conversation.utterance: user joined the chat.

Hey there! Happy to have you on board for our masterclass :-) Today you will be learning how to prepare the best Pesto. Make sure you have all the ingredients and tools and feel free to ask questions. If you are ready to start cooking simply say start.
start
Do you have any questions regarding the tools required or the ingredients?
is it important that the mortar is made from marble?

Yes, the type of mortar you use plays a crucial role.  A Thai granite mortar produces a much better pesto compared to a ceramic one. However,  the most effective is the Italian marble mortar with the large wooden pestle.

Are you planning to use Pecorino Fiore Sardo or a different type of cheese?
You mean a different type of Pecorino?
So,  historically, the cheeses of true Ligurian pesto were Parmigiano-Reggiano and Pecorino Sardo (or Fiore Sardo), a Sardinian sheep's-milk cheese. However,  Pecorino Romano can be used as well.

provenance.page_title: How to Make the Best Pesto
provenance.section_title: What Cheese Should Be Used in Pesto Sauce?
provenance.paragraph_text: Historically, the cheeses of true Ligurian pesto were Parmigiano-Reggiano and Pecorino Sardo (or Fiore Sardo), a Sardinian sheep's-milk cheese.

provenance.page_title: How to Make the Best Pesto
provenance.section_title: What Cheese Should Be Used in Pesto Sauce?
provenance.paragraph_text: When pesto first became popular in the United States, however, Fiore Sardo was pretty much unavailable here, so recipe writers substituted the next best available thing: Pecorino Romano.

conversation.utterance: OK fine, I can only get Pecorino Romano, but that should not be a problem then.
That's perfect! However, remember that Pecorino Romano is saltier, sharper, and tangier than Fiore Sardo.

provenance.page_title: How to Make the Best Pesto
provenance.section_title: What Cheese Should Be Used in Pesto Sauce?
provenance.paragraph_text: But Pecorino Romano is saltier, sharper, and tangier than Fiore Sardo.

conversation.utterance: Does that mean I should use less?

One question I wanted to ask: pine nuts are very expensive and I appreciate that the genuine pesto uses them. I have seen that commercial pestos use cashews. Can then be used as a substitute and what is the consequence for taste of the final dish?
That is a great question!  As you mentioned most recipes for pesto sauce call for pine nuts, but walnuts are not unheard of. So the flavour will only be affected marginally

conversation.utterance: Ah, that is a question I wanted to ask. Is there an different in result?
Sorry, typo: Is there any difference in result if you use the 'lazy' method, i.e. the food processor? Other than the halo around my head?

That is a great question! Yes, there is quite an important difference which becomes evident once you put the pesto sauce on the pasta.  The mortar-and-pestle pesto coats the noodles beautifully, bathing them in a gorgeous green-tinted sauce. By contrast, the food processor pesto just sticks to the pasta in little bits, like glitter, and the oil absorbs little of the basil's colour.

Is this the real 'original' recipe for pesto?
Don't worry about it! I'm here to help you to make the best pesto so feel free to ask any question you might have!
This recipe closely follows the original pesto recipe.  The most famous, and the one we're talking about here, is pesto alla genovese, from the Ligurian city of Genoa and its environs.

conversation.utterance: However, notice that Pesto is a more generic Italian term that describes a wide variety of puréed sauces, traditionally made using a mortar and pestle.

provenance.page_title: How to Make the Best Pesto
provenance.section_title: What Is Pesto Sauce?
provenance.paragraph_text: Pesto is a more generic Italian term that describes a wide variety of puréed sauces, traditionally made using a mortar and pestle.

conversation.utterance: There are other pesto sauces worth knowing about, though, including Sicily’s blushing-red pesto alla trapanese, which is rich with tomatoes; southern France's pistou (a version without nuts); and many, many more.

That looks delicious and so different from the stuff in jars.
How long can/could I keep it? Can it be frozen?
Let me see what I can find

So making pesto and freezing it doesn't work well due to the Parmesan cheese component. You could get around this by making a mix of the chopped/blended basil and olive oil, and freezing that combination. With that, you may also be able to add your salt & garlic as well.

provenance.page_title: Is there an organic preservative that I can add to homemade pesto to extend its refrigerated shelf-life?
provenance.section_title: Answer 1
provenance.paragraph_text: I'm not totally certain whether you're trying to end up with room-temperature shelf-stable pesto.  If so, you may have to look elsewhere.  However, my family has grown bumper crops of basil before, and been left with the task of trying to preserve it for year-round pesto.You noted that making pesto and freezing it doesn't work well due to the Parmesan cheese component. We would get around this by making a mix of the chopped/blended basil and olive oil, and freezing that combination. With that, you may also be able to add your salt & garlic as well, though I've not personally tried that, nor with including the pine nuts in the frozen package.This does require the recipient to make additions on their end, but it does preserve the basil well.  We would keep ziplocs of the basil-oil slurry in the freezer, and then done the end steps of adding the pine nuts/Parmesan/garlic and such.I think that's fairly similar to what the answer in the question you linked does, but I can confirm that it preserves well and the mixture stays a dark green, not brown.  If you're pretty sure that the packages are going to stay at freezer temperatures, I'd be confident in it working well.  I'm not sure at what temperature you'd start having issues, as that's not something that we experimented with.

conversation.utterance: however, I'm not sure for how long you should be able to keep it refrigerated
Thank you. Sounds like freezing it would be an expensive mistake after all the work. So one must not make more than required that or the net day.
Precisely!
